titleStmt.title: Revisions to Henry David Thoreau's manuscript of Walden

publicationStmt.p: Final Project for ENGL 340, Literature and Literary Study in the Digital Age, Spring 2020, SUNY Geneseo.

sourceDesc.bibl: A page from HM 924, the manuscript of Walden, "The Ponds", Paragraph 5c, Version F

zone.note: A look at the changes that Thoreau made in the Walden manuscript on page 50 of Version F, as compared to pages 55-56 in Version E. This is a transcription of all writing on page 50 of Version F.
zone.line: which last appeared but mud-
dy in comparison.
It is of a vitreous greenish
blue, as I remember it, like those
patches of the winter sky seen through
cloud vistas in the west before sundown.
Yet a single glass of its water held
up to the light is almost as color
less as an equal quantity of air.
It is well known likewise that so a large plate of glass will
have a green tint, owing, as the
makers say, to its body, but a
small piece of the same will be
colorless. How large a body of
Walden water would be required
to reflect a green tint I have
never proved.
The water of the our river is black, or
a very dark brown to one looking
directly down on it, and like of that of most
ponds, it imparts to the body of one
the bathing in it a yellowish tinge, but
this water is of such crystalline purity
that the body of the bather ap-
pears of an alabaster or chalky
whiteness equally still more unnatural, which,
as the limbs are magnified and
distorted withal, produces a mon-
strous effect, making fit studies for a Michael Angelo.
